Description: Doll carved from animal bone, with incised details representing a nude standing female figure with her hands clasped over her stomach.
Curator's comments: On dolls of this type: A. Shatil, "Bone Figurines of the Early Islamic Period: The So Called 'Coptic Dolls' from Palestine and Egypt", in: S. Vitezović, ed. Close to the Bone: Current Studies in Bone Technologies (Belgrade 2016) 296-314.
Bibliographic references: Akbarnia et al 2018 / The Islamic World: a History in Objects (p.108, fig.1)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2012 14 Mar - 8 Jul, New York, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 'Byzantium and Islam: Age of Transition'
Acquisition name: Transferred from: Victoria and Albert Museum
Acquisition notes: -To be exhibited in Byzantium and Islam: Age of Transition (7th - 9th Century) at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, from 12 March to 8 July 2012
